title: Da'ud ibn Isa
text:
Da’ūd ibn ‘Īsá ibn Fulaytah al-Ḥasanī al-‘Alawī (; d. July/August 1193) was <a href="Emir%20of%20Mecca">Emir of Mecca</a> at least three times between 1175 and 1192, in opposition to his brother <a href="Mukaththir">Mukaththir</a>. He belonged to the <a href="sharif">sharif</a>ian dynasty known as the Hawashim.
Da'ud succeeded to the Emirate after the death of his father <a href="Isa%20ibn%20Fulaytah">Isa</a> on 2 Sha'ban 570 <a href="Hijri%20year">AH</a> (). Less than a year later, on the night of 15 Rajab 571 AH (), he was deposed by his brother Mukaththir. In Dhu al-Hijjah of that year (June/July 1176) the Iraqi "<a href="amir%20al-hajj">amir al-hajj</a>" Tashtakin fought Mukaththir and captured Mecca. He gave custodianship of the Emirate to <a href="Qasim%20ibn%20Muhanna">Qasim ibn Muhanna</a>, the Emir of Medina. After three days Qasim surrendered the Emirate to Da'ud, after the latter agreed to Tashtakin's conditions, among which were that he abolish the "mukus" (non-Islamic taxes). However, reports indicate that Mukaththir was again Emir the following year, in 572 AH (1176/1177).
At some point the Emirate returned to Da'ud, as <a href="al-Dhahabi">al-Dhahabi</a> reports that he was Emir in 587 AH (1191/1192). He writes that in that year Da'ud looted the <a href="Kaaba">Kaaba</a> of its wealth and stripped the <a href="Black%20Stone">Black Stone</a> of its silver collar. When the "amir al-hajj" arrived he deposed Da'ud and installed Mukaththir as Emir. According to al-Dhahabi, Da'ud spent the rest of his days at <a href="Nakhla%20%28Saudi%20Arabia%29">Nakhlah</a>, where he died in Rajab 589 AH (July/August 1193). Najm Ibn Fahd writes that he died on Monday, 14 Sha'ban 589 AH (23 August 1193). He had a son named Ahmad, as evidenced by a gravestone seen by al-Fasi.
